entry.title: Viva sem Tabaco has been certified by HONCode
entry.content:
Good news!! We have been certified by the Health on the Net Foundation. What does it mean? It means that our content is compliant with the Code of Ethics of the most used and trustworthy code for medical and health information available on Internet. This is good for intervention users and also good for researchers and developers. As you probably know, Viva sem Tabaco is open-source and you are able build on it. You can check our certificate out here.

We are also seeking collaboration partners because it is really hard to keep all languages updated. So if you can speak English, Spanish, German or Russian, you are more than encouraged to reach us. If you know a different language, you can also translate the project and help smokers quitting. Students are more than welcome!

Screenshot

Take a look at our new intervention version that is about to be released.

Viva sem Tabaco has been certified by HONCode was originally published by Henrique Pinto Gomide at Live without tobacco project. on October 02, 2015.

entry.title: How browserstack is helping us to test our project.
entry.content:
We are pleased to announce that Browserstack is offering us their Live plan for free. Why did they do that? Our project is open-source and they love to support open-source projects.

What is Browser Stack?

Are you bored testing the compatibility of your website across the infinite number of browsers and OS’s?

BrowserStack offers to developers instant access to all desktop and mobile browsers, making your compatibility tests way easier.

If you also work on an open-source project, you can apply for a free license (they will gently ask you to add their logo on your project’s page). They also offer special prices for freelancers and a 30-day free trial.

How browserstack is helping us to test our project. was originally published by Henrique Pinto Gomide at Live without tobacco project. on August 17, 2015.

entry.title: Mobile version is under way!
entry.content:
Good news!! We are preparing a mobile friendly version of Live without tobacco. Before jumping into the mobile application world, we decided to make our project mobile-friendly using the front-end framework Materialize. Materialize is a modern responsive framework based on Material Design, the Google’s approach to design.

Where can I find the code?

The code is available in wati-bootstrap branch. Feel free to explore. We welcome any help and feedback! :)

Release date

We are working hard to release this version in late September.

Screenshots

Are you curious to watch the results we’ve got so far? Take a look.

entry.title: Live without tobacco - version 0.3 released
entry.content:
We are really pleased to announce that the 0.3 version of Viva sem Tabaco is released; it is named after Carlos Chagas.

Version notes

  • Added Fagerstrom Test of Nicotine Dependence - FTND - in the “Ready to quit” section. The test provides feedback to its users.
  • Added Patient Health Questionnaire 2 - PHQ2 - in the “Is it worth stopping smoking?” section. The test also provides feedback to its users.
  • Added Patient Health Questionnaire 9 - PHQ9 - in the “Ready to quit” section. The test provides feedback to its users.
  • Added motivation rule to evaluate motivation in the “Ready to quit” section.
  • Added pages “benefits of quitting” and “risks of smoking” in the “Ready to quit” section.
  • Added information about efficaccy of methods of quit smoking. Users fill what they have tried and receive feedback.
  • Added partial support do Russian. Now only Portuguese is fully supported. English, Spanish and German are also partially supported.
  • Fix of minor bugs.

The code is available in our github repository.

Live without tobacco - version 0.3 released was originally published by Henrique Pinto Gomide at Live without tobacco project. on July 29, 2015.

entry.title: Привет! Russian is now partially supported.
entry.content:
Dr. Dmytro Khvotenko, a Postdoctoral Researcher (and also owner of the lovely pug Axel), has translated the Viva sem Tabaco content into Russian. Russian is the official language in Russia, Belarus, Kazakhstan, and Kyrgyzstan and widely spoken language in Ukraine, Moldova, Latvia, Estonia, and to a lesser extent, the other countries that were once constituent republics of the Soviet Union. It is estimated that 260 million people speak russian1. Besides, approximately half of russian men smoke2.

The full support of Russian is expected to come out at the end of 2015. We would also like to invite the scientific community from Russian to join our project! :)

  1. Russian language. (2015, July 29). In Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia. Retrieved from (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russian_language&oldid=673619229) ↩

  2. Gilmore, A., Pomerleau, J., McKee, M., Rose, R., Haerpfer, C. W., Rotman, D., & Tumanov, S. (2004). Prevalence of Smoking in 8 Countries of the Former Soviet Union: Results From the Living Conditions, Lifestyles and Health Study. American Journal of Public Health, 94(12), 2177–2187. ↩

Привет! Russian is now partially supported. was originally published by Henrique Pinto Gomide at Live without tobacco project. on June 22, 2015.
